description: From Middle English streight, streght, streiȝt, the past participle of strecchen (“to stretch”), from Old English streċċan (past participle ġestreaht, ġestreht), from Proto-West Germanic *strakkjan (“to stretch”). Doublet of straught.

entries.meaning: Not crooked or bent; having a constant direction throughout its length. [from 14th c.]
examples: The other people, I presume, are supposed to be standing to attention, but they're all smiling at me. The lines are not even straight.

entries.meaning: (of a path, trajectory, etc.) Direct, undeviating. [from 15th c.]
examples: Now, as the world knows, the straightest way to the heart of the honest voter is through the women of the land, and the straightest way to the heart of the women is through the children of the land; and one method of winning both, with rural politicians, is to kiss the babies wide and far.

entries.meaning: Perfectly horizontal or vertical; not diagonal or oblique. [from 17th c.]
examples: Mr. Coniff: He did not have his hat on straight; that is the one thing, is it?

entries.meaning: (cricket) Describing the bat as held so as not to incline to either side; on, or near a line running between the two wickets. [from 19th c.]
examples: Steyn continues and it's all a bit more orderly down his end as O'Brien defends the first three balls with a straight bat and a respectful dip of the head.

entries.meaning: Direct in communication; unevasive, straightforward. [from 19th c.]
examples: Tony Blair issued a direct challenge to the IRA yesterday when he demanded they give straight answers to three simple questions […].

entries.meaning: Free from dishonesty; honest, law-abiding. [from 16th c.]
examples: ‘It wasn't the proper thing, squoire. It wasn't straight.’

entries.meaning: Serious rather than comedic.
examples: More success followed, both straight and comedic, with hits such as Dead Poets' Society (1989), in which Williams scored another Oscar nomination for skilfully handling a classic "rogue teacher" role that hovers just this side of sentimentality, […]

entries.meaning: In proper order; as it should be. [from 19th c.]
examples: "If you wonder why folks can't take the news seriously, here's Exhibit A," said one blogger. "Lord Jesus, how can the reporter file this story with a straight face?"

entries.meaning: In a row, in unbroken sequence; consecutive. [from 19th c.]
examples: After four straight wins, Mudchester United are top of the league.

entries.meaning: (tennis) Describing the sets in a match of which the winner did not lose a single set. [from 19th c.]
examples: Murray started well against Marcos Baghdatis before slumping to defeat in straight sets and the British No1 admitted he may not have been mentally prepared for the rigours of the ATP Tour after a gruelling start to 2011.

entries.meaning: (US, politics) Making no exceptions or deviations in one's support of the organization and candidates of a political party.
examples: a straight Republican
a straight Democrat

entries.meaning: (US, politics) Containing the names of all the regularly nominated candidates of a single party and no others.
examples: a straight ballot

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Conventional; mainstream; socially acceptable. [from 20th c.]
examples: ‘Her last album was a bit too straight,’ he says, ‘but this one puts her in a more contemporary framework and softens her music.’

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Heterosexual.
examples: Synonym: hetero

entries.meaning: (colloquial, of a romantic or sexual relation) Occurring between people of opposite sex (sometimes, but not always, specifically between heterosexual people).
examples: straight marriage, sex, relationships

entries.meaning: (slang, sex work) Related to conventional sexual intercourse.
examples: Coordinate term: French

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Not using alcohol, drugs, etc. [from 20th c.]
examples: Synonym: straightedge

entries.meaning: (fashion) Not plus size; thin.
examples: The shirts only come in straight sizes, not in plus sizes.
shopping at a straight-sized store

entries.meaning: (rare, now chiefly religion) Strait; narrow.
(obsolete) Stretched out; fully extended. [15th–16th c.]
(slang) Thorough; utter; unqualified.
examples: A real pimp is a gentleman, but these are pimps in gorilla suits. They hang around pimps, they have hoes on the track working for them, they may even look like pimps, but they are straight simps.

entries.meaning: Of spirits: undiluted, unmixed; neat. [from 19th c.]

(sciences, mathematics) Concerning the property allowing the parallel transport of vectors along a course that keeps tangent vectors remain as such throughout that course (a course which is straight, a straight curve, is a geodesic).

adverbs.description: straight (comparative more straight, superlative most straight)

entries.meaning: Of a direction relative to the subject, precisely; as if following a direct line.
examples: The door will be straight ahead of you.
Go straight back.

entries.meaning: Directly; without pause, delay or detour.
examples: On arriving at work, he went straight to his office.

entries.meaning: Continuously; without interruption or pause.
examples: He claims he can hold his breath for three minutes straight.

entries.meaning: Of speech or information, without prevarication or holding back; directly; straightforwardly; plainly.
Something that is not crooked or bent such as a part of a road or track.
(poker) Five cards in sequence.
(colloquial) A heterosexual.
examples: Synonyms: hetero, breeder
My friends call straights "heteros".

entries.meaning: (slang) A normal person; someone in mainstream society.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:mainstreamer

entries.meaning: (slang) A cigarette, particularly one containing tobacco instead of marijuana. [from 20th c.]
examples: Synonym: straighter

entries.meaning: A chiropractor who relies solely on spinal adjustment, with no other treatments.
examples: Antonym: mixer

verbs.description: straight (third-person singular simple present straights, present participle straighting, simple past and past participle straighted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To straighten.
examples: One man draws out the wire , another straights it , a third cuts it , a fourth points it , a fifth grinds it at the top for receiving the head
